case_vignette:
A 66-year-old female with past medical history of right breast cancer treated with radiation presents with a slowly growing mass on the right breast. She states the spot initially began as a small bruise then progressively enlargened over the past few months and now spontaneously bleeds. Examination reveals a violaceous, red exophytic thick nodule on the right breast. An excisional biopsy reveals atypical pleomorphic endothelial cells lining ill-defined vascular spaces and prominent hemorrhage.  The diagnosis is angiosarcoma, a rare and aggressive form of cancer that originates from the endothelial cells lining blood vessels.

Original text:
A 66-year-old man with past medical history of right breast cancer treated with radiation presents with a slowly growing mass on the right breast. He states the spot initially began as a small bruise then progressively enlargened over the past few months and now spontaneously bleeds. Examination reveals a violaceous, red exophytic thick nodule on the right breast. An excisional biopsy reveals atypical pleomorphic endothelial cells lining ill-defined vascular spaces and prominent hemorrhage.  The diagnosis is angiosarcoma, a rare and aggressive form of cancer that originates from the endothelial cells lining blood vessels.  (Note: Angiosarcoma is a rare cancer that can occur in the breast, but it is much more common in the skin, particularly on the scalp or face.) multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a slowly growing mass on my right breast that initially started as a small bruise and now it spontaneously bleeds.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for the past few months.
Do you have any personal or family history of breast cancer or other cancers?
Yes, I have a history of breast cancer in my right breast that was treated with radiation.
Have you noticed any changes in the skin texture over the mass, like puckering or dimpling?
No, but the mass has turned into a thick, red, bumpy nodule.
Have you experienced any weight loss, fever, or night sweats recently?
No, I have not experienced weight loss, fever, or night sweats recently.
Final Diagnosis: Cutaneous angiosarcoma of the breast.
